title: Hawaii visitor arrivals jump 6% in June as spending grows 4% to $1.3B
text:
Hawaii visitor arrivals jump 6% in June as spending grows 4% to $1.3B Jul 30, 2015, 1:28pm HST Industries & Tags Save Article A Lions Club International convention that brought nearly 18,000 delegates and their families to Waikiki last month helped push the number of visitor arrivals to Hawaii in June up by 6 percent, compared to the same month a year ago, while total spending rose 4 percent, according to preliminary statistics released by the Hawaii Tourism Authority on Thursday. For the first half of 2015, total visitor arrivals rose to 4.3 million visitors, an increase of 4 percent from 4.1 million during the same period in 2014. Total spending for the first six months of the year rose 3.5 percent to $7.6 billion, from $7.3 billion during the same period in 2014. Visitor arrivals for the month of June totaled 767,905, a 6 percent increase from 724,503 in June 2014, while total spending rose to $1.33 billion, a 4.4 percent increase from $1.28 billion in June of last year. An increase in the number of visitors from the West Coast has helped to offset a decline in the number of visitors from Japan this year. In June, the number of visitors from the U.S. West market rose 8 percent to 343,941, from 318,358 in June 2014, helping to boost the total for the first half of the year to 1.7 million, an 8.7 percent increase from 1.6 million during the first six months of the year. Spending by West Coast visitors rose 3.9 percent to $514 million in June, from $495 million during the same month last year, while spending for the first half of the year rose 7.3 percent to $2.6 billion, from $2.4 billion last year. The number of visitors from Japan in June declined by 2.3 percent to 118,911, from 121,711 in June 2014, which was consistent with the 2.1 percent decline during the first six months of the year to 688,517 visitors, from 703,297 during the first half of 2014. Spending by the Japan market fell 11.7 percent in June to $174 million, from $197 million last year, consistent with the 11 percent drop during the first half of 2015 to $987 million, from $1.1 billion during the first half of 2014. Likewise, an increase in the number of visitors from the U.S. East market helped to offset a decline in the number of visitors from Canada last month. There were 186,795 visitors from the East Coast in June, an 8.5 percent increase from the 172,235 visitors from the East Coast who came to Hawaii in June 2014, while the number who came during the first half of the year increased by 1.8 percent to 929,980, from 913,889 during the first half of 2014. East Coast visitors spent $391 million in June, a 10.2 percent increase from $355 million in June 2014, although spending for the first six months of the year declined by 1.4 percent to $1.92 billion, from $1.95 billion during the first half of 2014. The number of visitors from Canada in June declined 9.2 percent to 18,715, from 17,132 last year, while the total for the first six months of the year declined by 1.2 percent to 305,431, from 309,160 during the same time period last year. Spending by visitors from Canada fell 4.3 percent in June to $32.2 million, from $33.6 million in June 2014, while spending for the first half of the year by that market rose 3.6 percent to $670 million, from $646 million during the first six months of 2014.
